head.headtext: Distinction Between an Action for Breach of Confidence and an Action for Breach of Fiduciary Duty

para.paratext: In LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[1] La Forest J. found that the differences between fiduciary duties and duties of confidence include:

Duties of confidence can arise outside a direct relationship where, for example, a third party has received confidential information from a confidee in breach of the confidee's relationship to the confidor, whereas fiduciary duties arise only where there is a relationship between the parties.[2]
Breach of confidence will only be established where the innocent party can show that the offending party misused the information, whereas fiduciary law does not require harm to have resulted.
Remedies from both law and equity are available for breach of confidence, whereas equitable remedies alone are available for breach of fiduciary duty.
Finally, although a fiduciary relationship may, and almost always does, co-exist with an obligation to maintain confidence, the reverse is not true.
LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1989), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, at p. 36, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574. See also Liquid Veneer Co. v. Scott (1912), 29 R.P.C. 639 (Ch.), at p. 644.

LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1989), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574. However, where there is no relationship, but the defendants knowingly misused confidential information, there may be a cause of action in conversion: see Pinto v. Mancinelli (2008), 173 A.C.W.S. (3d) 755 (Ont. S.C.J.).
